elements.content: Selective CO2 adsorption over other small gases has been realized in an ultra-microporous metal–organic framework (MOF). In the quest of manifesting such selective carbon capture performance, the prefunctionalized linker strategy has been espoused. A new Zn­(II)-based three-dimensional, 3-fold interpenetrated metal–organic framework material [Zn­(PBDA)­(DPNI)] n ·xG (PBDA: 4,4′-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dibenzoic acid; DPNI: N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide; xG: x number of guest species) with unusual rob topology is synthesized following a typical solvothermal synthesis protocol, which gleans a modest CO2-selective adsorption trend over its congener gases (saturation CO2 uptake capacity: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g–1, at 298 and 273 K; volumetric single component isotherm based separation ratios at 0.2 bar: 189.4 (CO2/N2, 256.5 (CO2/H2), 12.3 (CO2/CH4); at 1 bar: 6.8 (CO2/N2, 17.1 (CO2/H2), 7.1 (CO2/CH4)). The compound also exhibits selective benzene sorption over its aliphatic C6-analogue cyclohexane. The structure–property correlation guided results supported by theoretical introspection further emphasize the omnipresent role of crystal engineering principles behind culmination of such targeted properties in the nanoporous MOF domain, to realize selective sorption facets.
elements.clean_text: Selective CO2 adsorption over other small gases has been realized in an ultra-microporous metal-organic framework (MOF). In the quest of manifesting such selective carbon capture performance, the prefunctionalized linker strategy has been espoused. A new Zn(II)-based three-dimensional, 3-fold interpenetrated metal-organic framework material [Zn(PBDA)(DPNI)] n ⋅xG (PBDA: 4,4'-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid; DPNI: N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide; xG: x number of guest species) with unusual rob topology is synthesized following a typical solvothermal synthesis protocol, which gleans a modest CO2-selective adsorption trend over its congener gases (saturation CO2 uptake capacity: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g-1, at 298 and 273 K; volumetric single component isotherm based separation ratios at 0.2 bar: 189.4 (CO2/N2, 256.5 (CO2/H2), 12.3 (CO2/CH4); at 1 bar: 6.8 (CO2/N2, 17.1 (CO2/H2), 7.1 (CO2/CH4)). The compound also exhibits selective benzene sorption over its aliphatic C6-analogue cyclohexane. The structure-property correlation guided results supported by theoretical introspection further emphasize the omnipresent role of crystal engineering principles behind culmination of such targeted properties in the nanoporous MOF domain, to realize selective sorption facets.

elements.content: Polar pore surface functionalization has been employed as an effective route to induce CO2 selective adsorption phenomena. A three-fold interpenetrated and structurally rigid three-dimensional ultra-microporous metal−organic framework (MOF) has proved itself as a suitable platform to exhibit selective interplay with CO2, owing to the electrostatics-driven interactions selectively realized in the case of the polarized adsorbate CO2 with the prefunctionalized MOF channels.
elements.clean_text: Polar pore surface functionalization has been employed as an effective route to induce CO2 selective adsorption phenomena. A three-fold interpenetrated and structurally rigid three-dimensional ultra-microporous metal-organic framework (MOF) has proved itself as a suitable platform to exhibit selective interplay with CO2, owing to the electrostatics-driven interactions selectively realized in the case of the polarized adsorbate CO2 with the prefunctionalized MOF channels.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Operational capturing and effective separation of the anthropogenic greenhouse gas CO2 poses an imperative challenge under various energy and environment-related contexts. A plethora of such relevant backdrops particularly focus upon drastically lessening the CO2 emission concomitant with precombustion technology based purification of natural gas, biogas, and landfill gas along with combustion of flue gas. Stupendous research efforts have been lately instigated toward the strategic development of chemically customized and permanently porous organic–inorganic hybrid network materials namely, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), aimed at selective CO2 removal from mixed gases.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Operational capturing and effective separation of the anthropogenic greenhouse gas CO2 poses an imperative challenge under various energy and environment-related contexts. A plethora of such relevant backdrops particularly focus upon drastically lessening the CO2 emission concomitant with precombustion technology based purification of natural gas, biogas, and landfill gas along with combustion of flue gas. Stupendous research efforts have been lately instigated toward the strategic development of chemically customized and permanently porous organic-inorganic hybrid network materials namely, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), aimed at selective CO2 removal from mixed gases.

elements.content: MOFs are arguably one of the most exciting functional materials in this milieu, owing to the sheer diversity and vast modular facet revolving around their designed syntheses. Recent developments in the crystal engineered MOF adsorbents’ regime has witnessed coherent pore surface engineering principles climb up the ladder to craft multifarious opportunities to systematically fine-tune and control performance. Apart from the seemingly interminable MOF research domain entailing massively high surface areas, benign crystal engineering approaches have steadily transpired as vital footprints to draw more and more impetus on rationally functionalized ultra-micropores. Upon the basis of suitable incorporation of linker or metal node-based functionalization principles, astute design and synthesis of such rationally integrated ultra-microporous (<0.7 nm) MOF adsorbents featuring both high uptake capacity and top-notch selectivity is an arduous task, considering the often encountered mutually exclusive nature of these two key parameters.
elements.clean_text: MOFs are arguably one of the most exciting functional materials in this milieu, owing to the sheer diversity and vast modular facet revolving around their designed syntheses. Recent developments in the crystal engineered MOF adsorbents' regime has witnessed coherent pore surface engineering principles climb up the ladder to craft multifarious opportunities to systematically fine-tune and control performance. Apart from the seemingly interminable MOF research domain entailing massively high surface areas, benign crystal engineering approaches have steadily transpired as vital footprints to draw more and more impetus on rationally functionalized ultra-micropores. Upon the basis of suitable incorporation of linker or metal node-based functionalization principles, astute design and synthesis of such rationally integrated ultra-microporous (<0.7 nm) MOF adsorbents featuring both high uptake capacity and top-notch selectivity is an arduous task, considering the often encountered mutually exclusive nature of these two key parameters.

elements.content: Recent MOF literature reports have markedly observed a striking upsurge in the development of deft structure–property correlation principles delivering an exquisite control over the fairly purposeful maneuvering of the open framework MOF lattices’ electronic natures. This has resulted in a rather systematic conceptualization of the coordination nanospace from the perspective of its desired functional attributes, emphasizing more on the emphatic role of linker based prefunctionalization approach while choosing apposite supramolecular building blocks to synthesize MOFs for a targeted deliverable, such as addressing the CO2 storage/separation frontier. The topical observation that even subtle electronic arrangements to the MOF pore walls typified by electron-deficient linker aided Lewis basic behavior of the adsorbent surface could indeed play crucial roles behind manifestation of selective electrostatic/charge-transfer interactions with the targeted adsorbate vapor led us to believe that a similar rationale might as well work in the cases of gleaning CO2 selective sorption trends. In fact, top-notch CO2 selectivity benchmarks could be well-realized by optimally adjusting the pore-size with the usage of smaller linkers, coupled with the crucial engagement of inorganic pillars reaping strong electrostatics with the polarized adsorbate. While quite a few literature reports highlight the assertive role of Lewis basic amine sites (LBS) to facilitate electrostatic interactions with CO2, a number of other reports have been registered encompassing instances where the genesis of selective CO2 interplay lies with the profusion of other polar functional groups (OFS) decorating the MOF Connolly surface. The most widespread approach to amplify the CO2-affinity and consequent selectivity for MOFs is to construct microporous structures replete with exposed metal cation sites (OMS) and LBS, and/or the dual combination of these two on their pore surfaces. However, the introduction of polar OFS (e.g., −F, −Br, −Cl, −CN, −OH, −SO3, −NO2, −CO2H) on the pore walls also affords similar electrostatic affinity and assists in the escalation of CO2–MOF interactions. In fact, for such cases, the augmentation of affinity for the OFS-functionalized frameworks toward CO2 becomes heavily reliant on the polarizing strength of the incorporated functional groups. However, as a counterbalancing event, these functional groups’ attachment to the MOFs’ pore wall often leads to considerable occupancy of void space in the associated cavities, and hence, reduces the free surface areas and guest-accessible volume of MOFs. Under this backdrop, we screened a library of carboxylate and N-donor linkers, which might possess electron-deficient attributes and therefore can be exploited as suitable prototypes for infusing similar electronic characteristics to the ensuing MOF pore surfaces.
elements.clean_text: Recent MOF literature reports have markedly observed a striking upsurge in the development of deft structure-property correlation principles delivering an exquisite control over the fairly purposeful maneuvering of the open framework MOF lattices' electronic natures. This has resulted in a rather systematic conceptualization of the coordination nanospace from the perspective of its desired functional attributes, emphasizing more on the emphatic role of linker based prefunctionalization approach while choosing apposite supramolecular building blocks to synthesize MOFs for a targeted deliverable, such as addressing the CO2 storage/separation frontier. The topical observation that even subtle electronic arrangements to the MOF pore walls typified by electron-deficient linker aided Lewis basic behavior of the adsorbent surface could indeed play crucial roles behind manifestation of selective electrostatic/charge-transfer interactions with the targeted adsorbate vapor led us to believe that a similar rationale might as well work in the cases of gleaning CO2 selective sorption trends. In fact, top-notch CO2 selectivity benchmarks could be well-realized by optimally adjusting the pore-size with the usage of smaller linkers, coupled with the crucial engagement of inorganic pillars reaping strong electrostatics with the polarized adsorbate. While quite a few literature reports highlight the assertive role of Lewis basic amine sites (LBS) to facilitate electrostatic interactions with CO2, a number of other reports have been registered encompassing instances where the genesis of selective CO2 interplay lies with the profusion of other polar functional groups (OFS) decorating the MOF Connolly surface. The most widespread approach to amplify the CO2-affinity and consequent selectivity for MOFs is to construct microporous structures replete with exposed metal cation sites (OMS) and LBS, and/or the dual combination of these two on their pore surfaces. However, the introduction of polar OFS (e.g., -F, -Br, -Cl, -CN, -OH, -SO3, -NO2, -CO2H) on the pore walls also affords similar electrostatic affinity and assists in the escalation of CO2-MOF interactions. In fact, for such cases, the augmentation of affinity for the OFS-functionalized frameworks toward CO2 becomes heavily reliant on the polarizing strength of the incorporated functional groups. However, as a counterbalancing event, these functional groups' attachment to the MOFs' pore wall often leads to considerable occupancy of void space in the associated cavities, and hence, reduces the free surface areas and guest-accessible volume of MOFs. Under this backdrop, we screened a library of carboxylate and N-donor linkers, which might possess electron-deficient attributes and therefore can be exploited as suitable prototypes for infusing similar electronic characteristics to the ensuing MOF pore surfaces.

elements.content: Electrostatic potential surface (E sp) calculations were executed with the Gaussian09 Rev D program suite using density functional theory (DFT) with Becke’s three-parameter hybrid exchange functional and the Lee–Yang–Parr correlation functional (B3LYP) and 6-31G­(d,p) basis set. The results stemmed from the described linker screening as approach yielded a few highly electron-deficient ones, indicated by their respective electrostatic potential surface plots, representative of the electron density maps ( solely illustrating the findings in the present case). Multivariate combinations of these assorted linkers were undergone solvothermal synthesis reactions with a variety of transition-metal ions, one of which ended up in the synthesis of a polar pore surface functionalized MOF (hereinafter, denoted as IPM-MOF-110; IPM–IISER Pune Materials) with its connolly surface’s inherent electronic nature inducing a reasonably selective CO2 interplay, as divulged in the ensuing discussion ().
elements.clean_text: Electrostatic potential surface (E sp) calculations were executed with the Gaussian09 Rev D program suite using density functional theory (DFT) with Becke's three-parameter hybrid exchange functional and the Lee-Yang-Parr correlation functional (B3LYP) and 6-31G(d,p) basis set. The results stemmed from the described linker screening as approach yielded a few highly electron-deficient ones, indicated by their respective electrostatic potential surface plots, representative of the electron density maps ( solely illustrating the findings in the present case). Multivariate combinations of these assorted linkers were undergone solvothermal synthesis reactions with a variety of transition-metal ions, one of which ended up in the synthesis of a polar pore surface functionalized MOF (hereinafter, denoted as IPM-MOF-110; IPM-IISER Pune Materials) with its connolly surface's inherent electronic nature inducing a reasonably selective CO2 interplay, as divulged in the ensuing discussion ().

elements.content: (a) Structure for the diimide linker N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide (DPNI or L′); (b) electrostatic potential surface for the ligand (L′), representative of the electron density map; (c) structure for the second constituent linker 4,4′-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dibenzoic acid (PBDA or LH2); (d) electrostatic potential surface for the LH2 linker, representative of its corresponding electron density map.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structure for the diimide linker N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide (DPNI or L'); (b) electrostatic potential surface for the ligand (L'), representative of the electron density map; (c) structure for the second constituent linker 4,4'-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid (PBDA or LH2); (d) electrostatic potential surface for the LH2 linker, representative of its corresponding electron density map.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Schematic Illustration of the Polar Pore Surface-Guided
Attainment
of Moderately Selective CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption Performance, Pursued
Herein</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2017-00141x_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of the Polar Pore Surface-Guided Attainment of Moderately Selective CO2 Adsorption Performance, Pursued Herein

elements.content: Comprehensive reaction-based screening of a number of 3d- and 4d-transition metal salts with precisely equimolar amounts of the dicarboxylate module PBDA (LH2) as well as, the N-donor diimide linker component DPNI (L′) under miscellaneous solvents and modulator combinations (syntheses and characterization for both the linkers: Schemes S1 and S2 and Figures S1–S6) were performed. One such typical solvothermal protocol with Zn­(II) led to the block-shaped, yellow single crystals of compound IPM-MOF-110 [Zn­(PBDA)­(DPNI)] n ·xG (xG denotes x numbers of disordered guest molecules) (Scheme S3). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) analysis of the MOF compound pointed out to the materialization of a three-dimensional (3D), 3-fold interpenetrated, open framework (a), which upon auxiliary intermolecular hydrogen bond formation with similar adjacent 3D networks emanated a six-connected self-penetrating network with rob (48.66.8) topology (IPM-MOF-110) (, Figures S7–S11), crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The symmetric neutral linker DPNI connects dinuclear zinc clusters to form a typical molecular building block (MBB) [Zn2(CO2)4N2]. The asymmetric unit comprises of one Zn­(II) center coordinatively bonded with one dicarboxylate PBDA (deprotonated form of LH2), alongside one diimide DPNI to form archetypal paddlewheel motifs (b). Topological analysis aided by the TOPOS program points out that the uninodal six-connected network of IPM-MOF-110 is of rob topology (point symbol: 48.66.8, vertex symbol: [4.4.4.4.4.­4.4.4.64.64.­68.68.68.68.*]), as an alternative to the often-found six-connecting α-Po (412.63, pcu) nets (Figure S11). The potential solvent- accessible area after excluding the guests is 2332.6 Å3 (28.6% of the unit cell volume), as calculated by the PLATON software. The coordination framework structure unveiled a periodic self-assembled organization of ultra-micropores (∼6.17 × 7.68 Å2; considering a single net) along the crystallographic a axis (c, as well as Figures S7–S9 in the Supporting Information) with electron-deficient DPNI and PBDA moieties adorning the porous channels. Such an electron-lacking linker surface rich arrangement in the open framework ultra-micropores should idealistically expedite strong interactions with the polarized adsorbate gas CO2, owing to the latter’s high quadruple moment. In addition, we observed that the framework could selectively adsorb the planar benzene and p-xylene (Figure S21) over aliphatic cyclohexane. This can primarily be ascribed to molecular sieving effect with supplementary contribution from pore-surface functionalization. Besides the pore size restriction leading to sieving effect for Bz/Cy, particle surface defects in the adsorbent bed might also result in blocking the diffusion of the larger adsorbate molecules (herein, Cy). It is noteworthy to mention that, to address the challenges of azeotropic mixture separation (C6 and/or C8), selective sorption of these azeotropic vapor adsorbates (benzene over cyclohexane) as manifested by the present material also marks an important facet.
elements.clean_text: Comprehensive reaction-based screening of a number of 3d- and 4d-transition metal salts with precisely equimolar amounts of the dicarboxylate module PBDA (LH2) as well as, the N-donor diimide linker component DPNI (L') under miscellaneous solvents and modulator combinations (syntheses and characterization for both the linkers: Schemes S1 and S2 and Figures S1-S6) were performed. One such typical solvothermal protocol with Zn(II) led to the block-shaped, yellow single crystals of compound IPM-MOF-110 [Zn(PBDA)(DPNI)] n ⋅xG (xG denotes x numbers of disordered guest molecules) (Scheme S3). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) analysis of the MOF compound pointed out to the materialization of a three-dimensional (3D), 3-fold interpenetrated, open framework (a), which upon auxiliary intermolecular hydrogen bond formation with similar adjacent 3D networks emanated a six-connected self-penetrating network with rob (48.66.8) topology (IPM-MOF-110) (, Figures S7-S11), crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The symmetric neutral linker DPNI connects dinuclear zinc clusters to form a typical molecular building block (MBB) [Zn2(CO2)4N2]. The asymmetric unit comprises of one Zn(II) center coordinatively bonded with one dicarboxylate PBDA (deprotonated form of LH2), alongside one diimide DPNI to form archetypal paddlewheel motifs (b). Topological analysis aided by the TOPOS program points out that the uninodal six-connected network of IPM-MOF-110 is of rob topology (point symbol: 48.66.8, vertex symbol: [4.4.4.4.4.4.4.4.64.64.68.68.68.68.*]), as an alternative to the often-found six-connecting α-Po (412.63, pcu) nets (Figure S11). The potential solvent- accessible area after excluding the guests is 2332.6 Å3 (28.6% of the unit cell volume), as calculated by the PLATON software. The coordination framework structure unveiled a periodic self-assembled organization of ultra-micropores (~6.17 × 7.68 Å2; considering a single net) along the crystallographic a axis (c, as well as Figures S7-S9 in the Supporting Information) with electron-deficient DPNI and PBDA moieties adorning the porous channels. Such an electron-lacking linker surface rich arrangement in the open framework ultra-micropores should idealistically expedite strong interactions with the polarized adsorbate gas CO2, owing to the latter's high quadruple moment. In addition, we observed that the framework could selectively adsorb the planar benzene and p-xylene (Figure S21) over aliphatic cyclohexane. This can primarily be ascribed to molecular sieving effect with supplementary contribution from pore-surface functionalization. Besides the pore size restriction leading to sieving effect for Bz/Cy, particle surface defects in the adsorbent bed might also result in blocking the diffusion of the larger adsorbate molecules (herein, Cy). It is noteworthy to mention that, to address the challenges of azeotropic mixture separation (C6 and/or C8), selective sorption of these azeotropic vapor adsorbates (benzene over cyclohexane) as manifested by the present material also marks an important facet.

elements.content: (a) Perspective view of the overall packing of IPM-MOF-110 (H atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) coordination environment constructing IPM-MOF-110, composed of two different linkers: L (PBDA) and L′ (DPNI) rendering channel functionalization; (c) pore surface engineering as manifested in a single pore’s ultra-microporous connolly surface; (d) single three-dimensional coordination network of IPM-MOF-110, viewed along the crystallographic b-axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Perspective view of the overall packing of IPM-MOF-110 (H atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) coordination environment constructing IPM-MOF-110, composed of two different linkers: L (PBDA) and L' (DPNI) rendering channel functionalization; (c) pore surface engineering as manifested in a single pore's ultra-microporous connolly surface; (d) single three-dimensional coordination network of IPM-MOF-110, viewed along the crystallographic b-axis.

elements.content: Albeit the fairly dense nature of the individual nets (Figures S7, S8, and S10), the internal voids (28.6% of unit cell volume; 2332.59 Å3, taking into account an optimal probe radius of 1.2 Å and grid spacing of 0.7 Å; PLATON) encompassing the parallel sheets seem amply spacious to allow the targeted small guest species (Figure S9). The thermogravimetric analysis profile (Figure S14) for this as-synthesized phase indicated that the free DMF guest species occluded inside IPM-MOF-110 could be completely removed by lower-boiling acetonitrile exchange protocol, followed by heating under a vacuum (additional FT-IR evidence of DMF removal: Figure S12; details of desolvation described in Supporting Information), to obtain the slightly pale yellow desolvated/guest-free crystals of the MOF (Figure S15 in the Supporting Information). The phase purity for the as-synthesized IPM-MOF-110 phase was confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S17), along with the SC-XRD-based unit cell inspection of a number of arbitrarily picked crystals (Figure S15). Furthermore, the structural rigidity attribute could be corroborated with all these PXRD patterns, owing to the absence of any dynamic nature within the self-penetrated Zn­(II) network, in spite of the involvement of two flexible ether nodes in one of the constituent linker PBDA. This can be rather understable from the standpoint of the thermodynamically stable Zn-based paddlewheel MBB’s inherent feature.
elements.clean_text: Albeit the fairly dense nature of the individual nets (Figures S7, S8, and S10), the internal voids (28.6% of unit cell volume; 2332.59 Å3, taking into account an optimal probe radius of 1.2 Å and grid spacing of 0.7 Å; PLATON) encompassing the parallel sheets seem amply spacious to allow the targeted small guest species (Figure S9). The thermogravimetric analysis profile (Figure S14) for this as-synthesized phase indicated that the free DMF guest species occluded inside IPM-MOF-110 could be completely removed by lower-boiling acetonitrile exchange protocol, followed by heating under a vacuum (additional FT-IR evidence of DMF removal: Figure S12; details of desolvation described in Supporting Information), to obtain the slightly pale yellow desolvated/guest-free crystals of the MOF (Figure S15 in the Supporting Information). The phase purity for the as-synthesized IPM-MOF-110 phase was confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S17), along with the SC-XRD-based unit cell inspection of a number of arbitrarily picked crystals (Figure S15). Furthermore, the structural rigidity attribute could be corroborated with all these PXRD patterns, owing to the absence of any dynamic nature within the self-penetrated Zn(II) network, in spite of the involvement of two flexible ether nodes in one of the constituent linker PBDA. This can be rather understable from the standpoint of the thermodynamically stable Zn-based paddlewheel MBB's inherent feature.

elements.content: Permanent ultra-microporous nature for the desolvated IPM-MOF-110 was established by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms recorded at 77 K, which show a reversible type I isotherm at low pressure (a). Langmuir and BET surface areas obtained from the low-pressure adsorption region (P/P 0 = 0.05–0.2) of this N2 adsorption isotherm are 986 and 937 m2 g–1 respectively, with an effective pore diameter of ∼6.4 Å (a, inset), suggestive of the framework’s inherent ultra-microporosity. Low temperature CO2 adsorption isotherm (recorded at 195 K) also showed a high uptake of ∼439 mL g–1, i.e., 19.6 mmol g–1 (b). However, more significantly, except CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.3 Å), IPM-MOF-110 exhibited only marginal uptake capacities for all other small gases [similar kinetic diameters: CH4 (3.76 Å), H2 (2.83 Å), N2 (3.64 Å), Ar (3.5 Å), and O2 (3.46 Å)] both at 298 and 273 K (c,d). The moderately high saturation storage capacities for CO2: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g–1, at 298 and 273 K respectively, correspond to ∼10.5 wt% and 15.1 wt% of the gas adsorbate CO2 (; Figures S18 and S19). Such selective uptake of CO2 (typified by its high quadruple moment: 1.34 × 10–39 Cm2) can be attributed to its favorable electrostatic interactions with the electron-deficient connolly surface of IPM-MOF-110, as reflected in the associated isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) value ∼32.1 kJmol–1 (Figure S20), at zero surface coverage [calculated by employing Dubinin–Radushkevich (DR) equation]. presents the single-component separation ratios of CO2/N2, CO2/H2, CO2/CH4, CO2/O2, and CO2/Ar delineated as (q 1/q 2) at a specified pressure (for which q i denotes the adsorbed amount of a pure gas feed), which were 6.8, 17.2, 7.1, 15.0, and 12.3 respectively for IPM-MOF-110, at 298 K and 1 atm.

</table-wrap>

On comparative assessment of this material’s CO2 storage capacity at ambient parameters: pressure (1 atm) and room temperature (298 K) with the literature reported MOFs, IPM-MOF-110 can be regarded as a moderately performing CO2-adsorbent MOF material, essentially ranking somewhat better among its analogous MOFs solely bearing other polar functional groups (OFS) (Tables S2 and S3). The adsorption selectivities (S ads) for the separations CO2/N2, CO2/O2, CO2/CH4, CO2/H2, and CO2/Ar were minutely calculated based on the ratios of the corresponding Henry’s adsorption constants: S ij = K H(CO2)/K H(j) (Table S4 and Figures S22–S33: virial parameters). The values of CO2/N2 selectivity ∼175 (273 K); ∼46 (298 K) makes this a promising candidate for postcombustion carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology. On the other hand, considerably good CO2/CH4 adsorption selectivity of ∼22 (273 K); ∼30 (298 K) indicates its viability for natural gas purification, while CO2/H2 separation selectivity of ∼836 (273 K); ∼75 (298 K) suggests its prospective applicability in precombustion CCS technology.
elements.clean_text: On comparative assessment of this material's CO2 storage capacity at ambient parameters: pressure (1 atm) and room temperature (298 K) with the literature reported MOFs, IPM-MOF-110 can be regarded as a moderately performing CO2-adsorbent MOF material, essentially ranking somewhat better among its analogous MOFs solely bearing other polar functional groups (OFS) (Tables S2 and S3). The adsorption selectivities (S ads) for the separations CO2/N2, CO2/O2, CO2/CH4, CO2/H2, and CO2/Ar were minutely calculated based on the ratios of the corresponding Henry's adsorption constants: S  ij  = K H(CO2)/K H(j) (Table S4 and Figures S22-S33: virial parameters). The values of CO2/N2 selectivity ~175 (273 K); ~46 (298 K) makes this a promising candidate for postcombustion carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology. On the other hand, considerably good CO2/CH4 adsorption selectivity of ~22 (273 K); ~30 (298 K) indicates its viability for natural gas purification, while CO2/H2 separation selectivity of ~836 (273 K); ~75 (298 K) suggests its prospective applicability in precombustion CCS technology.

elements.content: To further substantiate the experimental findings of selective CO2 storage/separation, dispersion-corrected density functional theory: DFT-D3 calculations were applied to assess the differential nature of interactions in case of different gas adsorbates with the IPM-MOF-110 Connolly surface, studied herein. As evident from the results assimilated in , polarized CO2 interacts more strongly with the framework than CH4 and N2 molecules. In particular, all the calculated binding energies based on the DFT-D3 method showed reasonably good agreement with the experimental sorption based heat of adsorption (Q st) data. As presented in a, following the anticipated prototype, CO2 interacts with both the oxygen atom of DPNI and the methyl group of PBDA linkers, facilitating its electrostatics driven moderately selective interplay. Additionally, binding energy of CO2 molecule in the absence of dispersion interactions (BE = −8.61 kJ/mol) indicate that a large fraction of the BE (∼73%) is contributed by the dispersion interactions. This is mainly attributed to the presence of narrow pore size.

As evident from the results assimilated in , polarized CO2 interacts more strongly with the framework than CH4 and N2 molecules. In particular, all the calculated binding energies based on the DFT-D3 method showed reasonably good agreement with the experimental sorption based heat of adsorption (Q st) data. As presented in a, following the anticipated prototype, CO2 interacts with both the oxygen atom of DPNI and the methyl group of PBDA linkers, facilitating its electrostatics driven moderately selective interplay. Additionally, binding energy of CO2 molecule in the absence of dispersion interactions (BE = -8.61 kJ/mol) indicate that a large fraction of the BE (~73%) is contributed by the dispersion interactions. This is mainly attributed to the presence of narrow pore size.

elements.content: (a–c) DFT-D3 optimized locations of CO2, CH4 and N2 molecules and their corresponding binding energies (BE) are shown below. Cluster cleaved from the unit cell is shown for clarity. Color code: Framework Zn, blue polygon; C, gray, H, white; O, red and N, blue. Guest molecules: CO2 - C, yellow; O, violet; CH4 - C, orange, H, green; N2 - N, blue, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a-c) DFT-D3 optimized locations of CO2, CH4 and N2 molecules and their corresponding binding energies (BE) are shown below. Cluster cleaved from the unit cell is shown for clarity. Color code: Framework Zn, blue polygon; C, gray, H, white; O, red and N, blue. Guest molecules: CO2 - C, yellow; O, violet; CH4 - C, orange, H, green; N2 - N, blue, respectively.

elements.content: To summarize, in the quest of deriving selective CO2 adsorption attributes with high storage performance, we have successfully implemented an electron-deficient, polar pore surface centered design principle in the ultra-microporous MOF domain. From synergistic amalgamation of experimental findings as well as theoretical introspection, the key role of electrostatics-driven interactions between the MOF Connolly surface and CO2 could be realized. From the perspective of gaining comprehensive understandings operative behind site-specific adsorbate–adsorbent interactions in the coordination nanospace, this underexplored mode of achieving cogent control over electronic properties of the microporous/ultra-microporous pore surface seems to possess a vital potential to play crucial roles in the impending target-driven approaches belonging to the crossroads of crystal engineering in the nanoporous MOF regime.
elements.clean_text: To summarize, in the quest of deriving selective CO2 adsorption attributes with high storage performance, we have successfully implemented an electron-deficient, polar pore surface centered design principle in the ultra-microporous MOF domain. From synergistic amalgamation of experimental findings as well as theoretical introspection, the key role of electrostatics-driven interactions between the MOF Connolly surface and CO2 could be realized. From the perspective of gaining comprehensive understandings operative behind site-specific adsorbate-adsorbent interactions in the coordination nanospace, this underexplored mode of achieving cogent control over electronic properties of the microporous/ultra-microporous pore surface seems to possess a vital potential to play crucial roles in the impending target-driven approaches belonging to the crossroads of crystal engineering in the nanoporous MOF regime.

cln_elements.content:
Selective CO2 adsorption over other small gases has been realized in an ultra-microporous metal–organic framework (MOF). In the quest of manifesting such selective carbon capture performance, the prefunctionalized linker strategy has been espoused. A new Zn­(II)-based three-dimensional, 3-fold interpenetrated metal–organic framework material [Zn­(PBDA)­(DPNI)] n ·xG (PBDA: 4,4′-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dibenzoic acid; DPNI: N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide; xG: x number of guest species) with unusual rob topology is synthesized following a typical solvothermal synthesis protocol, which gleans a modest CO2-selective adsorption trend over its congener gases (saturation CO2 uptake capacity: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g–1, at 298 and 273 K; volumetric single component isotherm based separation ratios at 0.2 bar: 189.4 (CO2/N2, 256.5 (CO2/H2), 12.3 (CO2/CH4); at 1 bar: 6.8 (CO2/N2, 17.1 (CO2/H2), 7.1 (CO2/CH4)). The compound also exhibits selective benzene sorption over its aliphatic C6-analogue cyclohexane. The structure–property correlation guided results supported by theoretical introspection further emphasize the omnipresent role of crystal engineering principles behind culmination of such targeted properties in the nanoporous MOF domain, to realize selective sorption facets.

Permanent ultra-microporous nature for the desolvated IPM-MOF-110 was established by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms recorded at 77 K, which show a reversible type I isotherm at low pressure (a). Langmuir and BET surface areas obtained from the low-pressure adsorption region (P/P 0 = 0.05–0.2) of this N2 adsorption isotherm are 986 and 937 m2 g–1 respectively, with an effective pore diameter of ∼6.4 Å (a, inset), suggestive of the framework’s inherent ultra-microporosity. Low temperature CO2 adsorption isotherm (recorded at 195 K) also showed a high uptake of ∼439 mL g–1, i.e., 19.6 mmol g–1 (b). However, more significantly, except CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.3 Å), IPM-MOF-110 exhibited only marginal uptake capacities for all other small gases [similar kinetic diameters: CH4 (3.76 Å), H2 (2.83 Å), N2 (3.64 Å), Ar (3.5 Å), and O2 (3.46 Å)] both at 298 and 273 K (c,d). The moderately high saturation storage capacities for CO2: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g–1, at 298 and 273 K respectively, correspond to ∼10.5 wt% and 15.1 wt% of the gas adsorbate CO2 (; Figures S18 and S19). Such selective uptake of CO2 (typified by its high quadruple moment: 1.34 × 10–39 Cm2) can be attributed to its favorable electrostatic interactions with the electron-deficient connolly surface of IPM-MOF-110, as reflected in the associated isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) value ∼32.1 kJmol–1 (Figure S20), at zero surface coverage [calculated by employing Dubinin–Radushkevich (DR) equation]. presents the single-component separation ratios of CO2/N2, CO2/H2, CO2/CH4, CO2/O2, and CO2/Ar delineated as (q 1/q 2) at a specified pressure (for which q i denotes the adsorbed amount of a pure gas feed), which were 6.8, 17.2, 7.1, 15.0, and 12.3 respectively for IPM-MOF-110, at 298 K and 1 atm.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Selective CO2 adsorption over other small gases has been realized in an ultra-microporous metal-organic framework (MOF). In the quest of manifesting such selective carbon capture performance, the prefunctionalized linker strategy has been espoused. A new Zn(II)-based three-dimensional, 3-fold interpenetrated metal-organic framework material [Zn(PBDA)(DPNI)] n ⋅xG (PBDA: 4,4'-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid; DPNI: N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide; xG: x number of guest species) with unusual rob topology is synthesized following a typical solvothermal synthesis protocol, which gleans a modest CO2-selective adsorption trend over its congener gases (saturation CO2 uptake capacity: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g-1, at 298 and 273 K; volumetric single component isotherm based separation ratios at 0.2 bar: 189.4 (CO2/N2, 256.5 (CO2/H2), 12.3 (CO2/CH4); at 1 bar: 6.8 (CO2/N2, 17.1 (CO2/H2), 7.1 (CO2/CH4)). The compound also exhibits selective benzene sorption over its aliphatic C6-analogue cyclohexane. The structure-property correlation guided results supported by theoretical introspection further emphasize the omnipresent role of crystal engineering principles behind culmination of such targeted properties in the nanoporous MOF domain, to realize selective sorption facets.

Permanent ultra-microporous nature for the desolvated IPM-MOF-110 was established by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms recorded at 77 K, which show a reversible type I isotherm at low pressure (a). Langmuir and BET surface areas obtained from the low-pressure adsorption region (P/P 0 = 0.05-0.2) of this N2 adsorption isotherm are 986 and 937 m2 g-1 respectively, with an effective pore diameter of ~6.4 Å (a, inset), suggestive of the framework's inherent ultra-microporosity. Low temperature CO2 adsorption isotherm (recorded at 195 K) also showed a high uptake of ~439 mL g-1, i.e., 19.6 mmol g-1 (b). However, more significantly, except CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.3 Å), IPM-MOF-110 exhibited only marginal uptake capacities for all other small gases [similar kinetic diameters: CH4 (3.76 Å), H2 (2.83 Å), N2 (3.64 Å), Ar (3.5 Å), and O2 (3.46 Å)] both at 298 and 273 K (c,d). The moderately high saturation storage capacities for CO2: 2.39 and 3.44 mmol g-1, at 298 and 273 K respectively, correspond to ~10.5 wt% and 15.1 wt% of the gas adsorbate CO2 (; Figures S18 and S19). Such selective uptake of CO2 (typified by its high quadruple moment: 1.34 × 10-39 Cm2) can be attributed to its favorable electrostatic interactions with the electron-deficient connolly surface of IPM-MOF-110, as reflected in the associated isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) value ~32.1 kJmol-1 (Figure S20), at zero surface coverage [calculated by employing Dubinin-Radushkevich (DR) equation].  presents the single-component separation ratios of CO2/N2, CO2/H2, CO2/CH4, CO2/O2, and CO2/Ar delineated as (q 1/q 2) at a specified pressure (for which q i denotes the adsorbed amount of a pure gas feed), which were 6.8, 17.2, 7.1, 15.0, and 12.3 respectively for IPM-MOF-110, at 298 K and 1 atm.

cln_elements.content: (a) Structure for the diimide linker N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide (DPNI or L′); (b) electrostatic potential surface for the ligand (L′), representative of the electron density map; (c) structure for the second constituent linker 4,4′-((2-(tert-butyl)-1,4-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dibenzoic acid (PBDA or LH2); (d) electrostatic potential surface for the LH2 linker, representative of its corresponding electron density map.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of the Polar Pore Surface-Guided Attainment of Moderately Selective CO2 Adsorption Performance, Pursued Herein

cln_elements.content: (a) Perspective view of the overall packing of IPM-MOF-110 (H atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) coordination environment constructing IPM-MOF-110, composed of two different linkers: L (PBDA) and L′ (DPNI) rendering channel functionalization; (c) pore surface engineering as manifested in a single pore’s ultra-microporous connolly surface; (d) single three-dimensional coordination network of IPM-MOF-110, viewed along the crystallographic b-axis.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Perspective view of the overall packing of IPM-MOF-110 (H atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) coordination environment constructing IPM-MOF-110, composed of two different linkers: L (PBDA) and L' (DPNI) rendering channel functionalization; (c) pore surface engineering as manifested in a single pore's ultra-microporous connolly surface; (d) single three-dimensional coordination network of IPM-MOF-110, viewed along the crystallographic b-axis.

cln_elements.content: Adsorption isotherms (a) for N2 (77 K), Inset: pore size distribution plot; (b) for CO2 (195 K); (c, d) for different gases (CO2, N2, H2, O2, CH4, and Ar) for compound IPM-MOF-110: (c) at 273 K; (d) at 298 K (filled markers: adsorption, hollow markers: desorption).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption isotherms (a) for N2 (77 K), Inset: pore size distribution plot; (b) for CO2 (195 K); (c, d) for different gases (CO2, N2, H2, O2, CH4, and Ar) for compound IPM-MOF-110: (c) at 273 K; (d) at 298 K (filled markers: adsorption, hollow markers: desorption).

cln_elements.content: (a–c) DFT-D3 optimized locations of CO2, CH4 and N2 molecules and their corresponding binding energies (BE) are shown below. Cluster cleaved from the unit cell is shown for clarity. Color code: Framework Zn, blue polygon; C, gray, H, white; O, red and N, blue. Guest molecules: CO2 - C, yellow; O, violet; CH4 - C, orange, H, green; N2 - N, blue, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a-c) DFT-D3 optimized locations of CO2, CH4 and N2 molecules and their corresponding binding energies (BE) are shown below. Cluster cleaved from the unit cell is shown for clarity. Color code: Framework Zn, blue polygon; C, gray, H, white; O, red and N, blue. metadata.title: Polar Pore Surface Guided Selective CO2 Adsorption in a Prefunctionalized Metal–Organic Framework
